 Thanks for the reply Kronus, your veiwpoint brings some comfort to me . One side of me would like to take that answer in whole faith and be done with it , the other side of me says it may not be this simple. :) I worked in a hospital for 12 years , that had a behavioral health center on the 3rd floor of it. I was called to that floor many times to help restrain violent mental patients, so I got to see first hand , the power of the mind (and physical body ! ) when distorted.
 I often wondered just how could a loving God condemn these people , the ones that when they got out of the hospital and had the first chance, they took their own life. The all forgiving loving God, is the side of me I would like to believe, and as I see yours too, Kronus.... but ...
 
 The other side of me (and my religous background , small as it was) motivates me to think there is a strong reasoning for the Bibles teachings and warnings about self destruction and the state of the self terminated person's soul in the hereafter. Life can most assuredly be hard for some people, and for some as we see , totally unbearable , therfore they end it. I have often wondered sometimes when I think of my passed friends, what if NO one was EVER knowledgable of the Bible or teachings of Christianity ? How many thousands of people daily trudge through life everyday , pushing on, knowing they have to, because in their heart they know their life is God's , and not theirs to take at will?? They fight on, finally passing the obstacle that makes them want to quit life, but they DIDN'T quit , solely because of the fear for their own soul being lost, if they committed suicide . ...
 
 If one looks at the suicide rate in this country now, it is alarming. I wonder how many of those taking their own life today, grew up without any instruction on Christ , and had not even a single thought of any existence beyond the grave ? I dont know whether or not it made a difference to those successful suicide victims or not , that being, their belief in a afterlife or not... 
 
 Twenty-seven years ago , I worked with a absolute great man named Bill, a man that was a professed Christian , and raising his family in a Christian home. He delivered lumber to our job sites daily , and was sent alone most of the time from the lumber yard. He had to carry the 4' x 8' sheets of 5/8 inch plywood by himself, sometimes a total of 75 of them , up two stories sometimes. We would help him sometimes if the builder wasnt around, but most of the time it was just Bill doing the mule work. Even with Bill being 55 years old, we never heard him complain or swear, just seen his red face and sweat soaked shirt , as he just went on about his work. 
 
 One morning another driver delivered our lumber , so we asked about where Bill was, and the new driver's reply was , " Didnt you hear ? Bill pulled over to the side of the road yesterday morning on the way to work , put a .38 in his mouth and pulled the trigger " . THAT is really when my questioning about people ending their own lives began, and just what the judgement on their souls would be . As with most suicides, we never found out why Bill shot himself , we just concluded that with him having so little education, being 55 years old, and with no way out of the HARD physical labor, he was seeing the end of his capability of working and providing for his family was near, so he terminated his physical existence. I dunno..... 
 
 I do know that all people have within them the capability of self destruction . I do know from my own life experiences around me, that people with depressive disorders are very subceptible to suicide. Even with todays marvels of medicine , they can sew up the brain, but cannot fix the mixed up signals it is putting out when a person is despondent, except maybe dull it with anti - depressants... 
 
 I personally feel that a belief in Christ, and the hereafter, would seem to have a profound effect on a person having suicidal thoughts. The fear of not knowing what happens to the self terminated person's soul , would have to be a deterrent to suicide, it seems. But then again what do I know, it didnt deter my friend Bill, :(

 There's different ways of taking one's life. There's the Islamic 'martyr', there's the Christian 'self-sacrifice', and then there's suicide (There may be other categories - I don't know - there's accidental death, but I don't think that falls into this discussion)
 
 The Suicide is one who kills him/herself in an act of despair.
 
 The Martyr in the Muslim sense is someone who kills him/herself and many others, for a particular politico-religious reason.
 
 The Self-Sacrifice is giving one's own life, for another person. Of the three, only this one is a truly self-less task. If you might recall the clichéd war film where some enemy throws a grenade into a trench and someone dives over it, to take it's full impact and protect the life of his buddies. That is self-sacrifice - giving one's own life to the aid of others. It is the term 'martyr used to be applied to, until Muslims started strapping bombs to themselves. Martyr in this sense vastly differs from the Christian concept in which the Christian martyr doesn't kill others in the process of self-sacrifice.
